annotation.text: Depletion of beta-arrestin-2 not only leads to increases (up to ~150%) in the induction of cleaved caspase-3 levels by treatment with hydrogen peroxide or etoposide, but also eliminates AngII-mediated decreases

On the other hand, knocking-down beta-arrestin-1 leads to decreases in apoptotic reagent-induced caspase-3 cleavage even in the absence of stimulation with AngII, which is similar in extent to the protection observed in AngII-treated control cells.

annotation.infon: positive regulation of release of cytochrome c from mitochondria|GO:0090200
annotation.text: However, unlike control siRNA-transfected cells, pre-stimulation with AngII fails to reverse the hydrogen peroxide-induced mitochondrial fragmentation in beta-arrestin-2 siRNA-transfected cells
On the contrary, we did not observe decreases in DNA fragmentation after prestimulation with AngII in beta-arrestin-2 siRNA-transfected cells
In the case of beta-arrestin-1 knock-down, effects on DNA fragmentation also mirror the effects observed with caspase-3 cleavage

annotation.infon: positive regulation of ERK1 and ERK2 cascade|GO:0070374
annotation.text: Here we demonstrate that in VSMCs stimulated with AngII, ERK1/2 are activated, and this is significantly reduced by siRNA-mediated knock-down of beta-arrestin-2 (Fig. 2, A-C).

In control siRNA-transfected cells, p90RSK phosphorylation also reaches a maximal level at 5 min after stimulation although it lags slightly behind ERK activation Silencing beta-arrestin-2 expression leads to rapid and transient p90RSK phosphorylation, also similar to ERK
In these cells, beta-arrestin-2 RNA interference interestingly leads to almost complete attenuation in AT1R-mediated BAD phosphorylation

annotation.infon: positive regulation of protein kinase B signaling cascade|GO:0051897
annotation.text: Accordingly, we tested the ability of AngII to promote phosphorylation of the stimulatory site, Ser473, of AKT in the VSMCs. As shown in Fig. 2, J and K, time-dependent phosphorylation was observed, which was inhibited by beta-arrestin-2 siRNAs at times later than 2 min of stimulation, indicating that this process is mediated in part by
decreases in these levels in cells overexpressing the wild-type BAD,

annotation.infon: positive regulation of protein kinase B signaling cascade|GO:0051897
annotation.text: Our results demonstrate that BAD phosphorylation by RSK is mediated predominantly by beta-arrestin-2-dependent signaling (Figs. 2G and 4E) and also suggest that its phosphorylation by AKT is partially dependent on
Our data show that knocking-down beta-arrestin-2 expression leads to almost complete inhibition in RSK-mediated phosphorylation of BAD following
